content: We have created a new stream, #covid-19, for dissemination of information and discussion related to the Covid-19 outbreak in Europe, including the CLAIRE volunteer effort to assist public institutions with containing and managing the situation (more on this very soon).

Dear Holger, this is just a great idea. The CIIRC team of Prof. Zdenek Hanzalek is now entering discussion with Czech officials to possibly implement the planning and scheduling algorithm for hospitals to mitigate the risk of insufficient resources (esp. beds with ventilation assistance). If anyone would like to contribute or is interested in this topic, please contact directly prof. Zdenek Hanzalek (Zdenek.Hanzalek@cvut.cz).
sender_full_name: Vít Dočkal (CLAIRE Office  Prague, CIIRC CTU)

content:
ANTI COVID 3D PRINTING TASK FORCE! N95 type respirator is the critical protective equipment to save the lives of medical doctors and other medical professionals. The sufficient number of respirators is not available on the market which causes the situation of emergency. CIIRC is currently developing own respirator and model for 3D printing. The prototype shall be ready for testing early next week. In case we are successful in tests, we will share the technical specification with all volunteering 3D printing labs for free during this emergency. If you are willing to join, click here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1JYibE7CwlBfFB4XAm2gxahZiLwovMeJNOCk6EKe_OzE/edit#gid=0

ANTI COVID 3D PRINTING TASK FORCE

sender_full_name: Vít Dočkal (CLAIRE Office  Prague, CIIRC CTU)

content:
Now we have a prototype of the respirator printed on a 3D printer with MJF technology. First tests are very promising and have shown minor improvements to be done. After the final prototype is verified we will focus on finding a way how to ensure mass production. One possibility is to design a form for the injection molding process. We will appreciate anyone who is experienced in designing the injection molding forms to discuss the requirements needed for a proper form to be produced. We expect the form could be also produced with additive manufacturing.The weight is 35g. With filter it will be around 50g. It fits well and seems to be well sealed.
It seems we are going a good direction.
89868432_335376287421221_4314624472255561728_n.jpg 89158088_1267448453451255_6398168516918247424_n.jpg

HELP NEEDED TO ENSURE MASS PRODUCTION:
Does anyone have experience with injection molding / pressure molding of silicon? If yes, please write me or sign up in google sheet.
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1JYibE7CwlBfFB4XAm2gxahZiLwovMeJNOCk6EKe_OzE/edit#gid=851438915

content:
March 15: The prototype of CIIRC RP95 Respirator has been upgraded. Now it is ready for membrane filters installation. The filter installation shall be tested tomorrow on Monday March 16. After the assembly, the CIIRC RP95 Respirator will be finally tested if meets the expected parameters.
image.png
sender_full_name: Vít Dočkal (CLAIRE Office  Prague, CIIRC CTU)

content:
We have built a robust method to predict the peak of the coronavirus contagion, and to identify where each country or region are on the contagion growth peak. It uses a Poisson autoregressive model for the new daily cases
Downloadable from
https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3551626

CIIRC RP95 Respirator. March 16: 3D print and molding combination - prototype upgraded
We have implemented silicon molding technology to produce sealing components and the valve. Silicon valve seems to be much better. The respirator fits perfectly and is very comfortable. Tomorrow we will fix the filters. We have already selected the manufacturer of the N95 certified nanomaterial. They are producing the ready made filters for the CIIRC RP95 respirator, we shall have it tomorrow. Tomorrow we, hopefully, will thus have the final prototype and will initiate the official approval procedure with the responsible authorities. Please use central email (above) for any communication. We are recievening so many important comments, which is fantastic! Thank you so much!
sender_full_name: Vít Dočkal (CLAIRE Office  Prague, CIIRC CTU)

content:
CLAIRE is working to collect the “AI & Covid-19” projects and efforts in Europe and to build and organise a network of AI experts and volunteers to work on these projects.

AI technologies can be a great support in fighting the corona virus, by working together, we can show the potential of AI, create a positive impact and ultimately share the best practices within the EU and the world.

Information on how to participate are coming soon.

Here is an interesting initiative.

The Allen Institute for AI has partnered with leading research groups to prepare and distribute the COVID-19 Open Research Dataset (CORD-19), a free resource of over 29,000 scholarly articles, including over 13,000 with full text, about COVID-19 and the coronavirus family of viruses for use by the global research community.
This dataset is intended to mobilize researchers to apply recent advances in natural language processing to generate new insights in support of the fight against this infectious disease. The corpus will be updated weekly as new research is published in peer-reviewed publications and archival services like bioRxiv, medRxiv, and others.
Please see: https://pages.semanticscholar.org/coronavirus-research for background, a free corpus, and a Kaggle competition.

CORD-19 | Semantic Scholar
CORD-19 (COVID-19 Open Research Dataset) is a free resource of over 29,000 scholarly articles about COVID-19 and the coronavirus family of viruses.

CIIRC RP95 respirator, update on March 18: the final prototype delivered to the Czech certification testing lab. Preliminary tests of the mask went well. We however need to change filters. We are in discussion with the filter manufacturer. The final test of the respirator will be performered hopefully today, if we find the proper solution for filters.

Can you share the 3D model?

Safe Paths
Safe Paths is an app that tells you if you have crossed paths with somebody who is infected, it shares information about your movements in a privacy-preserving way—and could let health officials tackle coronavirus hot spots. It is the “privacy compliant” version of the Chinese and South Korean app to track the movements of infected people.
It is a free and open-source app and it has been developed by a team at MIT Media Lab and Harvard.
https://www.technologyreview.com/s/615372/coronavirus-infection-tests-app-pandemic-location-privacy/
http://safepaths.mit.edu/

A new app would say if you’ve crossed paths with someone who is infected
Private Kit: Safe Paths shares information about your movements in a privacy-preserving way—and could let health officials tackle coronavirus hot spots.
